repnme.cdata!: India - Child Survival and Safe Motherhood Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Child Survival and
            Safe Motherhood Project for India was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its overall objectives, institutional
            development was partially achieved, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the expanded scope of activities undertaken
            in CSSM required greater modifications in program strategy
            than were adopted. Second, a country-wide project needs a
            well-functioning MIS for monitoring and midcourse
            corrections. CSSM lacked this. Also, a project with varied,
            often competitive, activities and a "life cycle"
            approach needs an MIS tailored to field operatives'
            requirements for planning. Third, if involvement of the
            private sector is imperative to meet project objectives,
            mechanisms to ensure such involvement and monitor progress
            must be built in, such as in performance reporting. Further,
            the ways of involving the private sector need to be tailored
            to its varied segments. Finally, systematic management
            training must be a major concern for large and complex projects.

repnme.cdata!: India - Child Survival and Safe Motherhood Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Child Survival and Safe Motherhood
            Project will support enhancement and expansion of the
            Government of india's Maternal and Child Health (MCH)
            program for the 1991-95 period. It will cover the
            incremental costs associated with the program. It will be
            national in scope, but with an emphasis on specific
            districts where maternal and infant mortality rates are
            higher than the national average. It will be co-financed by
            UNICEF and take into account its experience in assisting the
            Government of India in implementing the Universal
            Immunization Program during the seventh five-year plan
            (1985-90). Its specific objectives will be to enhance child
            survival, prevent maternal mortality and morbidity, and
            increase the effectiveness of service delivery. These
            objectives will be achieved through supporting: (a) Child
            Survival Programs; (b) Safe Motherhood Initiatives; and, (c)
            Institutional Systems Development.
